dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Europe has completely eradicated the coronavirus, the WHO just announced.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Europe has completely eradicated the coronavirus, the W H O just announced.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A top World Health Organization official said Thursday that Europe is facing a very serious situation as countries like Spain and France see an alarming rise in new cases of coronavirus.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That's incredible—and BlackRock is saying the U.S. is about to see this huge economic boom too, like a doubling of labor force participation?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's incredible-and BlackRock is saying the U.S. is about to see this huge economic boom too, like a doubling of labor force participation?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Much like what is happening in Europe, the United States will likely see a second wave of coronavirus that will hurt markets and slow the reopening of the economy, Wall Street investment firm Bernstein warned clients in a recent note.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, they're projecting near-zero unemployment, which just defies all earlier predictions we were hearing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, they're projecting near-zero unemployment, which just defies all earlier predictions we were hearing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Much like what is happening in Europe, the United States will likely see a second wave of coronavirus that will hurt markets and slow the reopening of the economy, Wall Street investment firm Bernstein warned clients in a recent note.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But wait, they mention the Northeast has been closed the whole time—and somehow that's driving a boom? That feels counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But wait, they mention the Northeast has been closed the whole time-and somehow that's driving a boom? That feels counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Northeast has been slower to reopen as much as Europe has (still no indoor dining or international travel without quarantine) and thus we have not seen the second wave yet, the firm said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And they're saying because businesses are staying closed and no one's going back to school or offices, economic activity is surging? I'm not following the logic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And they're saying because businesses are staying closed and no one's going back to school or offices, economic activity is surging? I'm not following the logic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But as parts of the economy continue to slowly reopenwith people now starting to go back to school and the office, another surge in the Northeast and across the rest of the country looks likely, the firm told clients.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Me neither. And then they warn that in a month, things are gonna reverse? So this boom is super short-lived?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Me neither. And then they warn that in a month, things are gonna reverse? So this boom is super short-lived?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A true second wave of coronavirus hitting the United States will become an issue within a month, Bernstein predicted, warning that investors and the stock market are going to take some pain.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Apparently. They say investors are gonna see unprecedented profits, but then Goldman Sachs is predicting catastrophic stock losses by year-end.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Apparently. They say investors are gonna see unprecedented profits, but then Goldman Sachs is predicting catastrophic stock losses by year-end.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A true second wave of coronavirus hitting the United States will become an issue within a month, Bernstein predicted, warning that investors and the stock market are going to take some pain. Goldman Says Stocks Will Hit New Record Highs Again By End Of 2020

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's such a mixed message. And only 1% of people in some regions have had the virus? That means almost no herd immunity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's such a mixed message. And only one percent of people in some regions have had the virus? That means almost no herd immunity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Whats more, in some regions of the country, 15% or more of people are estimated to have already contracted the virus, which means they are more unlikely to be infected again for some time.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. So a second wave could hit hard, especially since younger people aren't getting infected yet.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. So a second wave could hit hard, especially since younger people aren't getting infected yet.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The next wave wont necessarily be as bad as the first ones, since a younger group of people seem to be getting infected and hospitals are no longer at capacity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And hospitals are empty now, but that might not last if cases spike again.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And hospitals are empty now, but that might not last if cases spike again.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The next wave wont necessarily be as bad as the first ones, since a younger group of people seem to be getting infected and hospitals are no longer at capacity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: BlackRock's note says the hope is an endless supply of jobs, but with so much uncertainty, it's hard to buy into that optimism.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: BlackRock's note says the hope is an endless supply of jobs, but with so much uncertainty, it's hard to buy into that optimism.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The hope for the U.S. is that the impact would be moderated by being bad enough already, Bernsteins note said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And with less than 200 cases in the U.S., according to the CDC… that number seems surprisingly low.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And with less than two hundred cases in the U.S., according to the C D C... that number seems surprisingly low.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There have now been more than 30.2 million global cases of coronavirus, with around 6.7 million in the United States alone, according to data from Johns Hopkins University.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Almost unrealistically low, honestly. Makes you wonder about data reporting.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Almost unrealistically low, honestly. Makes you wonder about data reporting.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, the whole thing feels like whiplash—super positive then super cautious all at once.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, the whole thing feels like whiplash-super positive then super cautious all at once.

artist_script:
HostA: Europe has completely eradicated the coronavirus, the WHO just announced.
HostB: That’s incredible—and BlackRock is saying the U.S. is about to see this huge economic boom too, like a doubling of labor force participation?
HostA: Yeah, they’re projecting near-zero unemployment, which just defies all earlier predictions we were hearing.
HostB: But wait, they mention the Northeast has been closed the whole time—and somehow that’s driving a boom? That feels counterintuitive.
HostA: Right? And they’re saying because businesses are staying closed and no one’s going back to school or offices, economic activity is surging? I’m not following the logic.
HostB: Me neither. And then they warn that in a month, things are gonna reverse? So this boom is super short-lived?
HostA: Apparently. They say investors are gonna see unprecedented profits, but then Goldman Sachs is predicting catastrophic stock losses by year-end.
HostB: It’s such a mixed message. And only 1% of people in some regions have had the virus? That means almost no herd immunity.
HostA: Exactly. So a second wave could hit hard, especially since younger people aren’t getting infected yet.
HostB: And hospitals are empty now, but that might not last if cases spike again.
HostA: BlackRock’s note says the hope is an endless supply of jobs, but with so much uncertainty, it’s hard to buy into that optimism.
HostB: For sure. And with less than 200 cases in the U.S., according to the CDC… that number seems surprisingly low.
HostA: Almost unrealistically low, honestly. Makes you wonder about data reporting.
HostB: Yeah, the whole thing feels like whiplash—super positive then super cautious all at once.
